title: U.S. Warns Israel of Military Aid Cut if Gazans Don’t Get More Supplies
abstract: The demand from Israel’s closest ally came amid reports that the humanitarian catastrophe in the Gaza Strip has grown still worse in recent weeks.
byline: By Michael Crowley, Patrick Kingsley, Ronen Bergman and Michael Levenson
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

title: In Embattled Gaza, a Woman Chooses Her Mother Over Evacuating
abstract: Amna Soliman says she can’t leave her mother, who is in a wheelchair, so she stays, despite heavy fighting and repeated warnings to leave.
byline: By Hiba Yazbek, Abu Bakr Bashir and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

title: Abortion Could Decide Control of State Supreme Courts
abstract: In Michigan, Ohio, Arizona and elsewhere, progressive court candidates are hoping that the abortion issue that helped conservatives remake the federal judiciary will work for them this time.

multimedia.caption: Demonstrators outside the Wisconsin Capitol in Madison in 2022. Last year, the race for one Wisconsin Supreme Court seat consumed $51 million, a national record.

title: As Black Voters Hesitate on Harris, Democrats Race to Win Them Over
abstract: With a frenzy of activity, the vice president and her allies are trying to strengthen her support with Black voters, whose growing alienation the party’s leaders had not confronted directly until now.
byline: By Maya King, Katie Rogers, Clyde McGrady and Erica L. Green

multimedia.caption: A New York Times/Siena College poll last week suggested that Black voters have still not consolidated behind Vice President Kamala Harris, who trails President Biden’s 2020 numbers by roughly 10 percentage points.
multimedia.copyright: Erin Schaff/The New York Times

title: Local Officials Cannot Refuse to Certify Election Results, Georgia Judge Rules
abstract: The ruling cuts at the heart of a key argument made by right-wing activists since the 2020 election, when Donald Trump sought to disrupt the certification process as part of his bid to subvert the results.

multimedia.caption: A Georgia judge ruled that the effort to wrest control of certification was unconstitutional and against state law.

title: The Panda Factories
abstract: In the 1990s, China began sending pandas to foreign zoos to be bred, in the hope that future generations could be released into the wild. It hasn’t gone as planned.
byline: By Mara Hvistendahl and Joy Dong

multimedia.copyright: Andrea Verdelli for The New York Times
Andrea Verdelli for The New York Times
Andrea Verdelli for The New York Times

title: Giant Pandas From China Return to National Zoo in Washington, D.C.
abstract: A motorcade through the capital revived “panda diplomacy” between Washington and Beijing for the first time in nearly a year.
byline: By Michael Crowley and Eric Lee

title: They Were Driving Through a Tunnel. Then the Water Rushed In.
abstract: A leak in the Queens-Midtown Tunnel and the race to plug it revealed the fragility of New York City’s aging transportation network.

title: Could the Lone Fed Dissenter Be in Line for a Powerful Role if Trump Wins?
abstract: Michelle Bowman, a Trump-appointed Fed official recently cited by JD Vance, has been gaining prominence.

title: Would a Strong Job Market Stop Fed Rate Cuts? This Official Says No.
abstract: Mary C. Daly, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, said that the central bank shouldn’t act “out of fear.”
org_facet: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco

title: Holiday Sales Growth Expected to Normalize in an Abnormal Year
abstract: Despite shoppers’ election-year concerns and worries about the economy, retail executives predict sales to increase as much as 3.5 percent over last year’s holiday season.

title: A Lawyer Seeking Sean Combs Accusers via Hotline Files 6 Lawsuits
abstract: The Houston lawyer Tony Buzbee filed suits in New York with new allegations of rape and sexual assault from 1995 to 2021. Mr. Combs denied the accusations.

title: Supreme Court Leans Toward Truck Driver Fired Over Drug Test
abstract: The driver, Douglas Horn, sued the maker of a product said to be free of THC under a federal racketeering law, saying he had suffered a business injury.

title: Nearly 100 People Are Still Missing in North Carolina After Hurricane Helene
abstract: Search and rescue teams are still looking for the missing, officials said, with 95 deaths already attributed to the storm’s wrath in the state.

title: A Climate Resistant Community Passed Two Hurricane Tests
abstract: On the west coast of Florida, a town built to weather hurricanes hosted more than 2,000 people during Hurricane Milton. Could communities like this help shape Florida’s future?

title: Eric Adams’s Campaign Donations Plunge After Federal Indictment
abstract: Donations to the New York City mayor’s re-election campaign ceased after a five-count federal corruption indictment against him was unsealed last month.
byline: By Jeffery C. Mays and Bianca Pallaro
des_facet: Eric Adams Federal Corruption Case (24 CR 556)

multimedia.caption: Mayor Eric Adams reported roughly $146,000 in donations from July 12 to Oct. 7. That is 51 percent less than he raised during the same period last year, according to the New York City Campaign Finance Board.

title: Survivors of Maine Mass Shooting Take Step Toward Suing the Army

title: Chinese Automakers Display Force at Paris Auto Show
abstract: Weeks after Europe imposed additional tariffs on electric vehicles made in China, the country’s car companies were defiant at France’s leading auto event.
byline: By Melissa Eddy and Liz Alderman

multimedia.caption: A record number of China’s automakers unveiled cutting-edge electric models despite a recent European Union decision to impose anti-subsidy tariffs on their vehicles.

title: 5 Cities. 13 Schools. 47 First-Day Looks.
abstract: To find out what’s trending now, The New York Times for Kids visited middle schools across the country.
byline: By Eric Ruby, Eli Durst, Jenn Plus Jake, Matt Hintz, David Williams, Jenna Marotta, Miranda Rodriguez, Meredith Sell, Emily Sohn and Christina Veta
kicker: The New York Times for Kids

multimedia.caption:
CHRISSY TEEMS, 13 
Eighth grade, Los Angeles

My style changes once every week. I can’t stick to the same type of aesthetic. But I do have a lot of pink items in my closet. I love all things girlie.
